key_facts: Global temperatures in March were 1.6C above pre-industrial levels.
Europe had its warmest March on record.
Europe's March average rose 0.26C above the previous record in 2014.
Some European areas had their driest March on record.
Other European regions had their wettest March in at least 47 years.
Scientists warn every fraction of warming increases extreme weather events.
Central Asia endured an extreme heatwave linked to climate change.
Argentina experienced extreme rainfall fueled by climate change.
Arctic sea ice reached its lowest March extent in 47 years of satellite data.
The previous three months also set record lows for Arctic sea ice.
Copernicus Climate Change Service gathers billions of measurements worldwide.
The 1.5C global warming target may be slipping out of reach.
Warmer temperatures threaten to intensify heatwaves, droughts, and flooding.
